title: What is the best way to invest 10 lakh rupees in India? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many people have asked the same question on this Forum and I have replied more or less the same, except tailoring to their income & needs. The basic rules of investing involves knowing how much to invest and for how long? For that you need to know your surplus income/investable income to plan for your financial life. Gross sum is not useful, you need to plan out net income, expenses, possible savings etc before you embark on a financial planning journey. There are many ways to invest but investing systematically will help you in the long run. Before you start investing off, the first thing to do is have 6 months worth of your expenses in your bank account. This is because incase you lose your job (assuming you are a salaried employee) you will not have income, but expenses only till you find the next job. This money is to tide you over that period, which you can leave in an FD earning 7.25% pre tax. U need to take health insurance (take separately even if your employer provides one for you) for yourself (assuming you are single) early on, so that you can get exemption on pre-existing diseases later on. A Rs. 5 lakh policy should be more than sufficient which can be increased later on upon marriage or when you have children. Useful for tax exemption. After that you need to take term insurance (life insurance) to the amount equal to the liabilities/loans that you have so that incase of any unfortunate circumstances they will be paid in full. Term insurances are cheap in earlier part of life when you are young. A 1 cr term plan will cost you less than 10,000 Rs. Useful for tax exemption. Once you have secured all the above then you should start investing. Equity mutual funds, direct investing in stock markets will yield more than 18% on an average, if your holding period is more than 8 years. PPF, EPF, Corporate bonds, will yield anywhere between 6 - 9% on an average investment over a 15 year period. Liquid funds, fixed deposits, debentures, government bonds will yield a post tax return of 6.5% on an average holding period of 3 - 5 years. If you have a girl child aged <10 years, then you can invest in the sukanya samruddhi yojana for a maximum amount of Rs. 150,000. Details of the same are provided here. [1]  First, start investing in PPF for the maximum limit of Rs. 150,000 each year for a interest of 8.7% compounded annually for a period of 15 years, this will yield a sizable sum which you can use in 15 years for either starting your own business or down payment of the house or for your other needs. PPF also helps you in meeting the 80C requirements (tax exemption). Second, start investing in SIP of mutual funds - fixed amounts in the beginning and then start increasing the allocation by 10- 15% each year, as your salary increases. There are many good mutual funds that should get you started off. If you complete all these then you can start investing in direct equities, in small amounts across varied sectors. Invest Rs. 50,000 per month (or an amount based on your monthly income & savings) through SIP of 10 mutual funds spread across categories. Out of the below mentioned schemes, Pick 1 scheme from each sector/class. Also, pick growth option or dividend reinvestment option. Picking 2 funds in small and midcap is important, they act as a booster for your returns in some years giving 50 - 60% returns. Important to pick dividend reinvestment option, so that any dividend declared will be reinvested for you to get more units at a lower price as compared to future years. 1. Pharma 2. Banking 3. Technology 4. Power 5. FMCG 6. Large Cap 7. Small and Mid cap (S&M Cap) 8. Small and Mid cap (S&M Cap) 9. Diversified Equity 10. Balanced  You can do this allocation till you have exhausted the Rs. 10 lakhs or incase of a monthly income, for a period of 20 years or till your retirement, then I am sure you will have sizable amount that would have compounded at the rate of 15 - 18% each year. You would be financially secure and ready to support all your life goals of marriage, children's education, owning a home and leaving enough for retirement. Hope I have been able to provide you some direction. Incase you have any questions, please feel to write and I will be happy to help you out to the best of my knowledge. Happy Investing. Also read: How do I choose which mutual fund is good to invest?  Are mutual funds generally safe to invest in? There are N number of ways in which you can invest money in India. Each investment comes with the same risk as per the rewards. Let’s see what you can do get maximum rewards in India. How much each investment would give. Savings account: 4% Fixed deposit: 6.5% PPF: 8% Mutual funds: 8–16% Equities: 10–25% So according to me equities could give you maximum returns on year on year basis. Now how will you Invest 10 lakhs. My suggestion would to go with Fundamentally strong stocks and diversify your amount in different stocks from different sector. How to check fundamentally strong stocks? Always look for the company which is conflict free.Look for the company which has a sound management.Look for the company which has better future business prospects.These factors will help you choosing stocks for long term investments. Now let’s divide 10 lakhs in 10 different stocks. 1 Lakh in Reliance: One of the most valuable company in India. As we saw that Reliance is now debt free. Reliance can easily give around 10% returns on year on year basis.1 lakh in HDFC bank: One of the biggest private bank in India. HDFC bank has one of the most diversified business in India. The stock has given multibagger returns in past and it is expected to do so.1 Lakh in IRCTC: One of the monopolistic stock from railway sector. Government holds around 77% stake in IRCTC. As we see government is focusing on railways. The stock looks good for long term investments.1 Lakh in DMART: One of the biggest super market chain stores in India. The stock has already given 600% returns and it looks to give some great returns in future too! Dmart looks to get around 20–25% returns Year on Year.1 Lakh in SBI cards: One and only stock from cards sector. SBI cards looks good for long term investments. With growing digitalisation the stock will have a great future.1 Lakh in Infosys: One of the biggest IT giant. Looks good for longer term investments. INFOSYS has given some great returns in past and looks good to hold for some great returns.1 Lakh in HUL: One of the biggest FMCG stock. With the growing population HUL has a great opportunity in future. The stock has already given some multibagger returns and expected to give some great returns in future.1 Lakh in CIPLA: With growing demand in pharma sector. Cipla looks good to buy among all the pharma sectors.1 Lakh in Adani enterprises: Adani group is doing good now in India. With taking over Airports to expanding business overseas. Adani group looks good to hold for longer term.1 Lakh in Bajaj finance: One of the best stock from finance sector. With growing demand the stock looks to give good returns in future.In this way you can diversify 10 lakhs in different stocks from different sector. In this ways you can create your portfolio so that you won’t get affected by correction in a particular sector. Few tips to keep in mind: Always keep reviewing your portfolio.Take a exit if you find there is some internal conflicts.You can Invest through SIP in those stocks.Disclaimer: Kindly have your own analysis before investing in stocks.
